entry.title: users who did not complete an item that is revised by the item connect
entry.content:
Dear Experts,

We have used the item connector for update information of sevearl item, 

when updating an item in LMS, the system created a new  new Assigned Date record for the users who had that item. The solution was to modify the parameter  item.connector.defaultValue.revision.updateLearningPlans set to N , which resolved the issue for new loads performed through the connector. What is the best option for solve this issue?

entry.title: Re: Can I install multiple versions of SAP Crystal Report...
entry.content:
I've never tried Ido's solution, typically you can't mix versions, but Ido's is very creative so if he says it works then it likely does. When upgrading the CR for VS installer will uninstall the old version and upgrade to the latest MSI you install. Most of the time, it's better to manually uninstall the old runtime before upgrading.

I assume Ido's fix is you manually install the x86 MSI package for SP 18 and the 64 bit MSI for SP 38. Note you can get the MSI packages from here:

https://origin.softwaredownloads.sap.com/public/site/index.html

Also to be clear the 13.0.2000.0 and 13.0.4000.0 are the framework versions required CR to run. The actual version is x64: 13.0.38.5404

Look in Programs and Features to see the version number.

There may be a possible solution for you though, see this KBA:

2719939 - Crystal Reports for Visual Studio Runtime versioning - side by side ability - what to do with WinFormCRViewer.zip from download WIKI

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/2719939

Note, due to upgrades on the SAP site the zip file is no longer available but the KBA has info on how to use the redirect for the old programs to use the latest runtime.

You basically create a config file for those older programs to load the updated MSI packages and set them to the older version using a redirect command. Note the KBA is quite old so not 100% sure it works with the latest.

Also note that at the end of this year, 2025, the no longer will be 32 bit runtime available, R&D determined since 32 is old enough that you no longer need to build 32 bit applications, all versions of Windows can use 64 bit OS's. And 32 bit versions of Windows is not supported.

Time to upgrade those legacy applications to 64 bit platforms. Check with the makers to see if they have updates. If they are internal app's then simply rebuild them using the latest SP. See this blog I wrote on upgrading:

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/upgrading-a-visual-studio-2008-gt-2022-net-project-with-the-latest-cr-net/ba-p/13469215

The other issue could be CR for VS uses Microsoft app rules and they changed, the CR assemblies are now in a different location.

The old location was under this tree: C:\Windows\assembly

It's now under this tree: C:\Windows\Microsoft.NET\assembly

To sum up:

1. CR's SP 18 is very old, missing a lot of the security and dependencies require

2. 32 bit application support is ending this year

3. Third party dependencies have also ended for the older version.

4. If needed you can still compile your app use X86 in the TheCPU setting and using CR's x64 bit runtime. Changing the value to x86 mode you will see the CR assemblies still being directed to the x64 folder.

5. UPGRADE those older applications, it's the safest way to resolve this...

entry.title: Re: How does S/4HANA handle scenarios where the commodity...
entry.content:
In ECC, when the commodity code's unit of measure (UOM) differs from the material's base UOM, the system prompts you to enter a conversion factor during material master maintenance. This ensures correct reporting for Intrastat and foreign trade declarations.

However, in S/4HANA (especially from version 2020 onward), this conversion factor prompt is no longer available directly in the material master. SAP has restructured how commodity codes and UOM conversions are handled, particularly in the context of International Trade and Group Reporting.

In S/4HANA, commodity code maintenance is decoupled from the material master. You now use the Fiori app “Manage Commodity Codes” to Assign commodity codes, maintain UOMs and conversion factors and link them to material groups or product categories.

SAP expects conversion factors to be maintained via external trade data or custom tables, not manually in the material master. You can use custom logic or BAdIs to fetch conversion factors during reporting or declaration.

If you're uploading materials via LTMC or Migration Cockpit, you can include conversion factors in the Commodity Code template. This is the preferred method for initial data load or mass updates.

entry.title: Re: Condition Contract with Quantity Scale - Settlement A...
entry.content:
As of now, SAP S/4HANA does not offer a standard condition type like REBD for quantity-based contracts to manually adjust business volume. However, there are workarounds and enhancement options you can explore:

You can create a custom condition type (similar to REBD but for quantity) and configure it to post delta quantities. This requires defining a new condition type in Settlement Management and enhancing the settlement logic to consider this delta quantity during scale determination.

SAP allows manual business volume uploads via transaction WB2R_BUSVOL or through Fiori apps. You can upload missing quantities manually using Material, Customer, Contract reference, Quantity and UoM. This is especially useful when billing documents fail to post correctly or are missing due to master data issues.

You can implement this BAdI BADI_BUSINESS_VOLUME to inject additional business volume during the settlement process. This is the most flexible option and allows you to pull data from external sources, add missing quantities dynamically and ensure correct scale level is picked

entry.title: Outbound Transportation from MFG site having EWM,StRM, Lean Warehouse under one Freight Order to DC
entry.content:
Many Industries consider the manufacturing location as a plant in SAP. Under the plant, many storage locations would be available in SAP and some of them would be either IM managed (or Lean Warehouse managed), or Stock Room Managed (StRM) or EWM managed. As a part of the distribution process from the manufacturing site, there would be every chance that the different products from all these types of warehouses need to be shipped to other DC site or to the customer.

This blog covers my personal insights about the outbound process in SAP from MFG (manufacturing) site to other DC (distribution center) or to the customer wherein the different products are picked up from Lean Warehouse, StRM and EWM managed warehouse locations and loaded onto the the same vehicle under the single Freight Order (FO) with the help of SAP EWM and SAP TM ASR integration in basic S/4 HANA licence or in advanced S/4 HANA license using S/4 HANA 2023 FPS02 version. 

Process FLow - 

Process Flow - MFG Site (that has LE, StRM and EWM warehouse) to another DC / Customer in single Freight Order

Master Data -

  1. Maintain Loading Point location for EWM specific warehouse - transaction code # /SCMTMS/LOC3 -

Loading Point - EWM Warehouse

 2. Maintain Loading Point location for StRM specific warehouse - transaction code # /SCMTMS/LOC3 -

Loading Point - StRM Warehouse

3. Maintain Loading Point location for LE specific warehouse - transaction code # /SCMTMS/LOC3 -

Loading Point - LE Warehouse

4. Assign EWM Door in EWM Warehouse to the Loading Point - transaction code # /SCWM/DOOR_SCU -

Assign EWM Door to Loading Point

5. Assign StRM and LE Warehouse specific Door to the Loading Point - transaction code # /SCMTMS/M_ASRDOOR -

Assign StRM and LE Door to Loading Point

Documents in S/4 HANA -

1. Create multiple STO's from MFG plant to another DC.

2. Create multiple OBD's - 

EWM Relevant Delivery

Next -

StRM Relevant Delivery

Next -

Lean WH Relevant Delivery

3. Freight Unit (FU) gets created automatically and is further planned with the help of transportation cockpit automatically / manually and Freight Order (FO) is created and carrier is assigned based on the existing freight agreement arrangements.

Planning of Multiple Freight Units that have warehouse specific Loading Points

4. Perform each warehouse specific steps - picking, packing and staging.

5. Perform Arrival at the Door, Loading, Departure from the Door and PGI at Loading Point of LE Warehouse  - Fiori App - Load/Unload Freight Order.

Update in FO Execution Status after shipping steps in LE Warehouse

6. Perform Arrival at the Door, Loading, Departure from the Door and PGI at Loading Point of StRM Warehouse  - Fiori App - Load/Unload Freight Order.

FO Execution after Shipping steps in StRM Warehouse

7.Perform Arrival at the Door, Loading, Departure from the Door and PGI at Loading Point of EWMM Warehouse - Fiori App - Load/Unload Freight Order.

FO Status Overview at EWM Loading Point

Next -

FO Execution after Shipping steps in EWM Warehouse

Please share your comment and/or feedback in case of any suggestions.
Happy Reading !!!
Thanks
Prashant

Note -  The concept of usage of "Consignment Order" in ASR during the outbound process shipment for multiple customers will be covered in next blog.
Please follow topic to know more about SAP Extended Warehouse Management.
Please post and answer questions at here
Please read other posts on the topic at here

entry.title: Re: Fundamentals clean core
entry.content:
Hi @Mahmoud__Zeidan 

To ensure you have a clean core from scratch in your SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition system, here are the programs, tools, and approaches you should use:

  1. SAP Activate Methodology & Best Practices
  • Start your project with SAP Activate and leverage SAP Best Practices scope items for industry-standard business processes and test scripts.
  • Only activate the minimum necessary scope items to avoid unused features and data
  1. SAP Central Business Configuration
  • Use SAP Central Business Configuration for end-to-end configuration, controlling what business functions you use, and keeping tight control over your solution footprint.
  • Carefully define your organizational structure and master data for example plants, sales organisations and company codes to avoid unnecessary complexity.
  1. Standard Tools and Transactions for Core Maintenance
  • SPRO: Only make necessary customizations via SAP standard configuration and not custom code whenever possible.
  • SU01/SU10: User and role management, use template users as suggested in the starter guide.
  • Fiori Rapid Activation: Rapidly activate only needed apps and services.
  1. Custom Development Practices
  • Follow keep the core clean principles
  • Use in-app extensibility Fiori app Custom Fields and Logic for minor adaptations.
  • Use SAP Business Technology Platform side-by-side extensions for more complex enhancements. Avoid custom ABAP in the core when possible.
  • Document all custom developments and ensure they use released APIs and extension points.
  1. Monitoring and Housekeeping
  • Regularly review transaction codes, custom objects, and roles to remove obsolete items.
  • Use SAP Focused Run or ALM tools to monitor system health and integrations.
  • Perform regular security, data privacy, and authorization audits via security transactions and Fiori launchpad tools.
  1. Data & Integration Clean-up
  • Only interface or integrate with essential systems using SAP standard integration methods (e.g., OData services, SAP Cloud Connector).
  • Ensure all master and transactional data migrated is validated, deduplicated, and relevant.

 

I hope this provides the necessary details. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

Implementing SAP S/4HANA Service

Starter system for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition: Getting Started Guide

entry.title: Re: Issue with Subsequent Delivery Free of Charge in Adva...
entry.content:
Hello @aravindrawat 

The error Copying Requirement 304 that you are experiencing occurs because the Reason for Rejection is not set on the return item in the sales order. Unlike the on-premise system, where you can manually change this field (using transaction codes like VOV7/VFBS), SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition manages this automatically.

Explanation:

In the S4 Public Cloud, the system automatically determines the Reason for Rejection based on the follow-up activity chosen during the returns process.
For example, when you select Subsequent Delivery Free of Charge (activity 0002) as the follow-up, the system assigns the relevant rejection reason, marking the item as not billing relevant.
If the rejection reason is missing or not properly assigned, the SD processing step fails with the requirement 304 error.

Next Steps:

  • Please review and update the configuration under SSCUI 105513 – Define Logistical Follow-Up Activities.
  • Make sure a valid Reason for Rejection is assigned to follow-up activity 0002 Subsequent Delivery Free of Charge
  • Once set up correctly, the system will update this field automatically during processing, enabling the SD step to proceed smoothly.

Additional Notes:

  • This mechanism aligns with the standard process model in S/4HANA Cloud and eliminates the need for manual rejection reason entry in sales documents.
  • Direct manual modifications to this field in the sales order are not supported in the cloud edition.

For further details, you can refer to:

  • Logistical Follow-Up Activities - SAP Help Portal

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Cost Center Splitting Weights Integrated Financial Pl...
entry.content:
Hello @SANA11 

Based on the details provided, here are the Root Cause to the issue you are facing:

  • The % Splitting Weight you see is derived from a calculated measure based on a restricted measure
  • When you add or edit the restricted measure in the story, even without changing parameters SAC re-evaluates the calculation context.
  • The recalculation changes depending on:
  1. Versioning context for example Plan vs. Actual
  2. Filters or dimension hierarchies in the story vs. model
  3. Whether “Enable Constant Selection” is checked or unchecked in the calculation editor.

This is why you see the percentage changing when you edit or add the measure. The context shifts and SAC recomputes the formula.

 

Here is how i suggest fixing It

Step 1: Check Calculation Context

In the Calculation Editor:

  1. Go to Measures → Subtotal Driver 2.
  2. Ensure constant selection is enabled for Version (you seem to already have this, so it is good).
  3. Do the same for Splitting Weight if required.
  4. Save and recheck the story.

 

Step 2: Validate the Restricted Measure

  • Make sure Subtotal Driver 2 has the same restrictions in the story as in the model:
    • Go to Model → Measures → Subtotal Driver
    • Compare restrictions for example Cost Center Activity Type, Version and Driver Source.
    • If the story level measure uses different filters, SAC recalculates.

 

Step 3: Lock the Version

  • If your calculation should always be based on the Plan version:
  1. In the Calculation Editor, explicitly select Version = Plan.
  2. Confirm Enable Constant Selection is enabled so other story filters do not override it.

 

Step 4: Compare Story vs. Model Behaviour

  • If the model shows 50% but the story shows a different % after editing, it means
    • Your story filters or dimension drilldowns are overriding model restrictions.
    • To stabilize values, replicate the model calculation context exactly in the story.

SAP suggested best practice: Always manage restricted measures in the model, not in the story, when using standard content, otherwise SAC treats it as a new calculation.

I hope this provides the necessary details. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Query on Advanced Return Management for Service and N...
entry.content:
Hello @aravindrawat 

The error “Invalid Movement Type 657” occurs because ARM is designed for stock-relevant processes materials:

  • Movement Type 657 is used for returns-to-stock in ARM.
  • Service items (TATX) and NLAG (non-stock, e.g. KLN) do not involve inventory postings.
  • When ARM tries to post a goods movement, there is no stock, so the process fails.

In response to your question: It is not possible to use Advanced Returns Management for Service or NLAG items.

Possible Workaround:

  • Process these returns using a standard return order (without ARM), referring to the original invoice.
  • Exclude ARM flows such as automatic delivery or credit memo.

SAP Knowledge Base Article on Movement Type 657 in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 

This is standard system behaviour in S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition and not a configuration error.

With best regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: How to relay custom headers in SAP CALM alerts and pa...
entry.content:
Hello @IKhurana 

Thank you for your question.

Yes, you can leverage custom header details from SAP Integration Suite in SAP Cloud ALM alerts and include your business specific data such as Sales Order numbers or Purchase Order numbers in the incidents created in ServiceNow.

How is how you can achieve this:

  1. Pass Custom Business Data in Integration Suite:
    • In your integration flows on SAP Integration Suite, capture and propagate the custom header or message attributes containing business data.
    • Ensure that these details are included in the event payload when raising alerts or events from Integration Suite.
  2. Configure SAP Cloud ALM Alert Management:
    • Within SAP Cloud ALM, configure the alert rules and payload mapping to extract these custom fields from the incoming event messages.
    • Extend or enrich the alert content by mapping these business data fields into the alert description or custom fields.
  3. Integrate SAP Cloud ALM with ServiceNow Incident Management:
    • Use SAP Cloud ALM’s Event Integration or API-based integration methods to forward alerts to ServiceNow.
    • In the integration, ensure that the mapped alert payload that includes your business context is pushed to create enriched ServiceNow incident records.
    • This can be configured with SAP Integration Suite or native SAP Cloud ALM connectors or custom webhook configurations.
  4. Use SAP Cloud ALM Extensions or Custom Logic:
    • If necessary, use extension capabilities within SAP Cloud ALM or additional SAP Integration Suite flows to format and include business-relevant metadata in the incident creation call.

Integrate SAP Cloud ALM with External Incident Systems

I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Report for sales order milestone billing plans in S4H...
entry.content:
Hello @Haily 

You are correct, SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud does not offer a single standard report that consolidates milestone billing plan details, such as Sales Order, Billing Plan, Billing Status, and Billing Amount, all in one place.

Available options in Public Cloud:

  • App Manage Billing Plans F2824
    This app displays billing plan details, including dates, amounts, and status.
  • App Manage Sales Orders – Version 2 (F3893)
    Provides a transactional view useful for order tracking, but does not offer a consolidated billing plan report.
  • App Manage Billing Documents (F0797A)
    Provides information about invoice and billing statuses.

Best Practice for Reporting:

  • Utilise pre-delivered CDS views like I_SalesOrderBillingPlanItem and I_BillingDocumentItem.
  • Create a Custom CDS View that joins sales order billing plan data with billing document data.
  • Expose this data via a Custom Analytical Query and consume it through:
    • Fiori apps (custom analytical tiles),
    • SAP Analytics Cloud dashboards, or
    • Excel via OData services.

This approach is fully supported in the Public Cloud environment and is upgrade safe.

Here are some helpful SAP documentation references you might find useful.:

  • SAP Help Portal: Manage Billing Plans - Convergent Invoicing
  • SAP Community Blog: Project Billing for Customer Projects

Let me  know if you need further support

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Is there a way to generate a requote only with the ad...

Hello @Ingrid_at_Applium 

You are correct that in S/4HANA Public Edition, the Requote function always generates a completely new quotation with all accepted items. Currently, there is no out-of-the-box option or extensibility to create a follow-up quotation that includes only the new items.

entry.title: Re: SAP Signavio - Cosmetic configuration of shapes in Va...
entry.content:
Hi @alessandro_monticosta 

Thank you for your question.

Here is how you can Turn Off Shadows on Chevron Process Shapes

  • Currently, there is no direct toggle for shadows on chevron shapes in the standard Value Chain diagram editor. However, shadows and other effects are often part of the default style applied to process elements.
  • Here is a workaround: Upload a custom SVG shape without shadows and assign it to your process shapes:
    • Navigate to the Custom Graphics tab in your workspace setup.
    • Upload your custom SVG without shadow effects.
    • Assign this custom graphic to your chevron process shape on the diagram.
  • This effectively replaces the shadowed shape with your solid design.

 

How to Remove Gradient Fill on Rectangles and Have Solid Colour Fill

  • The gradient fill comes from the default style or theme applied to rectangle shapes.
  • Modify this by using custom styles or overriding the fill property:
    • In the diagram’s Attributes panel, check if you can specify a flat solid fill colour overriding the gradient.
    • If not available directly, use a custom SVG shape with your desired solid fill colour.
  • You can also try to adjust the diagram’s global theme settings or create a new colour palette without gradients.

I am happy to help if you have further questions. See links below for further details.

Best regards

Chris

 

Custom Graphics

Custom Process Modelling with Solution Processes

entry.title: Re: Delivery group functionality in Sales order item leve...
entry.content:
Hello @S0026934150 

Thank you for providing the screenshot. In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud version 2502, the Delivery Group (VBAP-GRKOR) field does not initiate outbound delivery splits. It is only used to group items for delivery together; it does not influence how delivery splits are managed.

Here's why your delivery wasn't split

The delivery split logic in Public Cloud relies on the following standard header-level criteria that determine delivery creation and division,

  • Shipping Point
  • Ship-to Party
  • Delivery or Requested Date/Time
  • Route, Incoterms, or other predefined header-level attributes

The VBAP-GRKOR field isn't included in this logic, so it's not possible to set it up or modify it to trigger delivery splits.

What you can do to get separate deliveries:

  • Assign different values to one or more supported fields, such as varying requested delivery dates, shipping points, or routes for the respective items.
  • Alternatively, the system will generate a single outbound delivery, which you can split manually after creation if needed.

Here are some helpful SAP Documentation References that you might find useful.

  • SAP Knowledge Base Article (KBA) confirming this behaviour:
    KBA 3285286 – Delivery Split During Delivery Creation in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
    SAP Support Portal - KBA 3285286
  • SAP Community discussions on delivery split criteria:
    Outbound Delivery Split Criteria and Convergence

Let me know if you need further support

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Setting Default Values in RAP Entity Creation: Default Values Functions, Actions, and Augmentation
entry.content:
Setting default values when creating a new entity is a common requirement in RAP-based application development. Currently, there are three options available: Default Values Function, Default Factory Action, and Augmentation. In this blog post, I will walk through the implementation of each technique and explain when to use them. 

Quick Comparison of Defaulting Options in RAP

Here is a summary of the three options for setting default values in RAP entity creation.

 

Default Values Function

Default Factory Action

Augmentation

Can set default values for the root entity?

✔

✔

✔

Can accept parameters?

✖

✔

✖

Can create child entities along with the root entity?

✖

✔

✔

Can set defaults when creating a child entity independently?

✔

✖

✔

 

When to Use Each Approach

  • Default Values Function: Best when you want to set static default values. “Static” here still allows values depending on runtime context, such as the logged-in user, the current date, values from related entities.

  • Default Factory Action: Use this when defaults need to be determined dynamically based on user input. It can also create child entities together with the root entity. However, it cannot be used for creating child entities independently; in that case, use a Default Values Function or Augmentation.

  • Augmentation: This is defined at the projection layer, not at the base behavior definition. It is mainly useful when you cannot or do not want to change the base behavior.

 

Notes on Combining the Methods

These methods cannot be combined for the same entity. 

  • Default Values Function + Augmentation → Both are called, but only the values from the Default Values Function are applied.

  • Default Values Function + Default Factory Action → Only the action is executed, but no default values are set.

  • Default Factory Action + Augmentation → Only the action is executed, but no default values are set.

👉In practice, always choose one method per entity.

⚠️The above results are based on my own testing, not on official documentation. There may be inaccuracies.

 

Sample Code

In all of the following examples, the root entity is Employee and the child entity is Address.
Each method demonstrates how to set default values for Employee as well as for Address (when applicable).

1. Default Values Function

Behavior Definition

Define default values functions. 

Note: GetDefaultsForCreate is the predefined function name and can be omitted.

  // Default values for the root entity  
  create {default function GetDefaultsForCreate; }

  // Default values for the child entity (via create-by-association)  
  association _Address {create {default function GetDefaultsForCBA;}  with draft;}

Behavior Projection

Expose default values functions.

  use function GetDefaultsForCreate;
  use function GetDefaultsForCBA;

Behavior Implementation

  METHOD GetDefaultsForCreate.
    result = value #( for key in keys (
               %cid = key-%cid
               %param-LastName = 'Default Last Name'
                ) ).
  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD GetDefaultsForCBA.
    result = value #( for key in keys (
                      %tky = key-%tky
                      %param-Purpose = 'Default Purpose'
                    ) ).
  ENDMETHOD.

 

2. Default Factory Action

Behavior Definition

Define a default factory action. In this example, an input parameter ZABS_EMPLOYEE_INPUT is used. If no input is required, the parameter can be omitted.

static default factory action MyDefaultActionForCreate parameter ZABS_EMPLOYEE_INPUT [1];

ZABS_EMPLOYEE_INPUT is defined as a CDS abstract entity.

@EndUserText.label: 'Input for employee default action'
define abstract entity ZABS_EMPLOYEE_INPUT
{
    @EndUserText.label: 'Employee Type'
    EmployeeType: abap.int1;    
}

Behavior Projection

Expose the default factory action.

  use action MyDefaultActionForCreate;

Behavior Implementation

  METHOD MyDefaultActionForCreate.
    DATA employee_create TYPE TABLE FOR CREATE zr_employee_2508.
    DATA employee_create_line TYPE STRUCTURE FOR CREATE zr_employee_2508.
    DATA address_create TYPE TABLE FOR CREATE zr_employee_2508\_Address.
    DATA address_create_line TYPE STRUCTURE FOR CREATE zr_employee_2508\_Address.

    LOOP AT keys INTO DATA(key).
      " Set default data for Employee
      employee_create_line = VALUE #(
        %cid = key-%cid
        %is_draft = key-%param-%is_draft
        FirstName = SWITCH #( key-%param-EmployeeType
                              WHEN 1 THEN 'Default 1'
                              WHEN 2 THEN 'Default 2'
                              WHEN 3 THEN '' )
        %control = VALUE #( FirstName = if_abap_behv=>mk-on )
       ).
      APPEND employee_create_line TO employee_create.

      " Set default data for Address
      address_create_line = VALUE #(
       %cid_ref = key-%cid
       %is_draft = key-%param-%is_draft
       %target = VALUE #( ( %cid = sy-tabix
                            %is_draft = key-%param-%is_draft
                            Purpose = 'Default'
                            %control = VALUE #( Purpose = if_abap_behv=>mk-on ) ) )
      ).
      APPEND address_create_line TO address_create.
    ENDLOOP.

    "Create new instance of Employee
    MODIFY ENTITIES OF zr_employee_2508 IN LOCAL MODE
      ENTITY Employee
      CREATE FROM employee_create
      CREATE BY \_Address
      FROM address_create
      MAPPED DATA(mapped_create).

    mapped-employee = mapped_create-employee.
    mapped-address = mapped_create-Address.

  ENDMETHOD.

 

3. Augmentation

Behavior Projection

Augmentations are defined only in the Behavior Projection. The keyword "augment" is used to define them.

  // Default values for the root entity  
  use create (augment);

  // Default values for the child entity (via create-by-association)  
  use association _Address {create (augment); with draft;}

Behavior Implementation

  METHOD augment_create.
    DATA employee_create TYPE TABLE FOR CREATE zr_employee_2508.
    DATA address_create TYPE TABLE FOR CREATE zr_employee_2508\_Address.
    DATA address_create_line TYPE STRUCTURE FOR CREATE zr_employee_2508\_Address.
    DATA relates_create TYPE abp_behv_relating_tab.
    DATA tabix TYPE sy-tabix.

    employee_create = CORRESPONDING #( entities ).

    LOOP AT employee_create ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<employee>).
      " Count table index for generating unique %cid for Address
      tabix = sy-tabix.
      APPEND tabix TO relates_create.

      " Set Default Data for Employee
      <employee>-DateOfBirth = '19900101'.
      <employee>-%control-DateOfBirth = if_abap_behv=>mk-on.

      " Set Default Data for Address
      address_create_line = VALUE #( %cid_ref = <employee>-%cid
                     %is_draft = <employee>-%is_draft
                     %key = <employee>-%key
                     %target = VALUE #( ( %cid = tabix
                                          %is_draft = <employee>-%is_draft
                                          Purpose = 'Augmented Address'
                                          %control = VALUE #( Purpose = if_abap_behv=>mk-on )
                                        ) )
                     ).
      APPEND address_create_line TO address_create.
    ENDLOOP.

    MODIFY AUGMENTING ENTITIES OF zr_employee_2508
      ENTITY Employee
      CREATE FROM employee_create
      CREATE BY \_Address
      FROM address_create
      RELATING TO entities BY relates_create.
  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD augment_cba_Address.
    DATA address_create TYPE TABLE FOR CREATE zr_employee_2508\_Address.
    DATA relates_update TYPE abp_behv_relating_tab.

    address_create = CORRESPONDING #( DEEP entities ).

    LOOP AT address_create ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<address>).
      LOOP AT <address>-%target ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<target>).
        <target>-Purpose = 'Augmented Address CBA'.
        <target>-%control = VALUE #( Purpose = if_abap_behv=>mk-on ).
      ENDLOOP.
    ENDLOOP.

    MODIFY AUGMENTING ENTITIES OF zr_employee_2508
      ENTITY Employee
      CREATE BY \_Address
      FROM address_create.

  ENDMETHOD.

 

Conclusion

When setting default values in RAP, you can choose between Default Values Function, Default Factory Action, and Augmentation.

  • Use Default Values Function for static defaults.

  • Use Default Factory Action for dynamic defaults or when creating child entities together with the root.

  • Use Augmentation only at the projection layer, when the base behavior cannot be changed.

 Since these methods cannot be combined for the same entity, always pick the one that best matches your scenario.

References

  • Operation Defaulting (Default Values Function) | SAP Help Portal
  • RAP - Default Factory Action  | ABAP Keyword Documentation
  • Editing Text for Supplements (Augmentation) | SAP Help Portal

entry.title: Re: CRM (C1P) - /dev/shm Mount Point Full on wkaws1033
entry.content:
Hi @PradeepKumar04 

The /dev/shm mount point getting full on your SAP CRM additional application server host often indicates shared memory usage issues. /dev/shm is a temporary file storage that resides in RAM and is commonly used for Inter-Process Communication such as semaphores and shared memory segments.

Here are the Common Root Causes:

  1. Unreleased Shared Memory Segments:
    Processes may create shared memory or semaphores but fail to release them properly after completion, causing /dev/shm to fill up.
  2. High Volume of Processes Using /dev/shm:
    Intensive applications or batch jobs may create large or numerous shared memory objects.
  3. Leaks in SAP or OS Resources:
    A bug or misconfiguration in SAP CRM or the underlying OS causing memory leaks in shared memory.
  4. Insufficient /dev/shm Size Configuration:
    The size for /dev/shm may be set too low relative to the RAM or workload requirements.

Here are recommended Checks and Actions:

  • Check your Shared Memory Usage:
    Run the following:

bash

df -h /dev/shm

ipcs -m    # List current shared memory segments

ipcs -s    # List semaphores

Identify orphaned or excessive segments.

  • Clear Stale Shared Memory:
    If you find shared memory segments belonging to processes no longer running, ensure you remove them manually using:

bash

ipcrm -m <shmid>

ipcrm -s <semid>

Be cautious and validate ownership before cleanup.

  • Check SAP Notes:
    There are SAP Notes related to /dev/shm not being released properly, e.g.
    SAP Note 706071  Linux: Memory in tmpfs is not released correctly
    SAP Note 1674325 DEV/SHM directory is used by multiple instances and prevents startup
  • Verify OS Limits and Configuration:
    Ensure /dev/shm size is configured appropriately in /etc/fstab or systemd tmpfs config, e.g. size=<suitable size>:

bash

mount | grep /dev/shm

Typical size is half the RAM or more depending on workload.

  • Monitor Processes in SAP:
    Look for hung or stuck SAP processes using transaction SM50/SM66 that might be holding IPC resources.
  • Restart SAP Instances Carefully:
    Sometimes, a restart may be needed to free IPC resources if manual cleanup is not feasible.

I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Vertex Tax Integration – Restrict Usage to Sales Tran...
entry.content:
Hello @Govind_Sharma 

Thank you for your enquiry regarding tax calculation and the use of user exits in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition.

The  user exits, such as EXIT_SAPLFYTX_USER_001 or BADI_MRM_TAX_CALCULATION, are not available—these are specific to on-premise or private edition systems. Instead, tax control is managed via scope selection and configuration activities.

Key Points:

Restrict Vertex to Sales only:

    • In Central Business Configuration (CBC), scope only External Tax Calculation – Sales, and do not scope the Procurement variant.
    • In the External Tax Calculation (SSCUI) configuration, set:
      • Application Area = SD (Sales) → External
      • Application Area = MM (Purchasing) → Internal
    • Ensure the SD tax procedure includes external tax condition types (e.g., UTXJ), while the MM tax procedure uses standard internal conditions.
    • Result: Vertex is invoked only for sales documents; procurement documents continue to use SAP’s internal tax logic.c.

Fixing Zero Tax on Customer Invoices:

    • A zero-tax amount from Vertex usually signals data issues, not connectivity.
    • Validate:
      • Address and jurisdiction data completeness for Ship-to party, Plant, and Company Code.
      • Pricing procedure includes the external tax condition, is not statistical, and contains an account key for posting.
      • Customer and material tax classifications are accurate (not exempt).
      • Vertex configuration mappings for company, registration, and products are correct and active, with no exemptions inadvertently applied.
    • Use the External Tax Calculation Log in SAP S/4HANA Cloud to check if the Vertex call succeeded and review returned tax rates.

Preventing Vertex Calls for Purchasing:

    • No user exits required.
    • Handled automatically by associating only the internal tax procedure for MM in the SSCUI configuration.
    • Vendor invoices and purchase orders thus use SAP internal tax calculation, and Vertex is bypassed.

The SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud manages tax integration through scope selection and SSCUI configuration, not via user exits or BADIs. Correctly setting the scope and configuration ensures Vertex is restricted to sales documents only. Most tax issues typically originate from master data or configuration errors rather than integration problems.

 

With kind regards

Chuma

 

 

GenIA Assist content

Helpful SAP Documentation References for You:

  • SAP Help: External Tax Calculation in SAP S/4HANA Cloud
  • SAP API Business Hub: Vertex Tax Integration Flows for SAP S/4HANA Cloud
  • Vertex: Vertex Resource Library

entry.title: Re: Cross-Company Code Cash Application – Withholding Tax...
entry.content:
Hello @R_Pooja 

The error message "Company Codes have different settings for withholding tax treatment" is normal in SAP S/4HANA public cloud. Automatic clearing between company codes is not available if they have different withholding tax configurations.

Reasons why this occurs,

When processing payments, the system verifies consistency in withholding tax settings across company codes. If, for example, company code DE01 and company code FR01 have different withholding tax parameters such as indicators or calculation methods, the system prevents the direct clearing process. This restriction aims to avoid inconsistent accounting postings caused by mismatched tax treatments.

Your current workaround:

Posting the bank statement on the account in DE01 and manually clearing it against the invoice in FR01 aligns with SAP’s standard behaviour in these scenarios and is the recommended method.

Possible solutions:

  • Standard SAP behaviour: There is no configuration option to override this check. This is documented in KBA 2186938, which applies to both on-premises and cloud editions.
  • Best practice: Align withholding tax configurations across all involved company codes, ensuring uniform withholding tax types and calculation methods. Once harmonised, the system will allow cross-company code clearing without errors.
  • Automation options in Public Cloud:
    • Use Advanced Bank Statement Processing (scope item 1EG) with posting rules to streamline posting bank statements and reduce manual clearing steps.
    • Consider Central Payments (scope item 1S4) in a Central Finance scenario, designed to handle cross-company receivables and payables more efficiently.

Please take a moment to review the helpful SAP documentation below

  • SAP Help App: Check Withholding Tax Settings and Simulate Calculation
  • SAP Help: Clearing Withholding Tax Items

Let me know if you need further support

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Optimizing Asset Maintenance Process In SAP S4HANA With Resource Scheduling
entry.content:
In this blog, I will be walking through how we can handle the resource scheduling for maintenance orders that are part of Phase Based Maintenance framework.

My Business Use Case:

My organization is a Calcined Process Industry and follows phase-based maintenance framework for Reactive and Proactive Maintenance activities. Lately, production team reported that the belt conveyor BC01 belt has torn and ripped in raw material handling area, i.e., Coke Pad. So I have created a Reactive Maintenance order for Belt Conveyor(BC01). Also, I do have scheduled Preventive Maintenance orders for Kiln-01, Belt Conveyor(BC02), and Belt Conveyor(BC03).

If you want to gain a deep understanding of Phase-Based maintenance framework, please find the blog links below.

  • Phase-Based Maintenance Process With Lean Services in SAP S4 HANA Asset Management. 

 

  • Let`s get down to nitty-gritty of "Manage Workflows for Maintenance Orders"-S4 HANA Asset Management 

 

  • Planning, Adding & Approving Lean Services Using Flexible Workflow in SAP S/4HANA Asset Management. 

The crux of the SAP S4HANA Asset Management "Resource Scheduling" :

Resource scheduling in SAP S4HANA enables efficient planning of maintenance tasks by providing visibility into workload, capacities, and work center utilization aspects. We can use the apps for resource scheduling to check current and forecasted work center utilization, build schedules, and determine required capacities before dispatching the scheduled work.

Key Benefits Include, but are not limited to:

  • Build an optimal schedule through simulation analysis for open maintenance orders before releasing for execution.
  • Group and Schedule maintenance orders by assets.
  • Control Maintenance Workloads by adjusting activities in the schedule.
  • Distribute Work evenly across capacities and collaborating across other schedulers.

I will be using FIORI Apps listed below for this walk through.

Mini Note: With an additional license, we can use "Resource Scheduling" for maintenance work centers and assign maintenance crew to these work centers. We can dispatch individual order operations and pass the maintenance orders to the "Execution Phase".

First things first...let us "Make Basic Settings for Resource Scheduling" and create a Work Center Team.

Creating work centers team can make planner or supervisor`s job easier, because they can choose suitable team members when they plan maintenance work. A work center can be linked to exactly one team, and a team can be linked to exactly one work center. In addition, a person can only be assigned to one work center team at a time.

For Instance, I have created four teams to represent the Mechanical, Electrical, Instrumentation, and Safety departments.

Mechanical Team:

Electrical Team:

Instrumentation Team:

Safety Team:

 

The overall teams for Calcination Maintenance are as follows:

 

Now let us get into our Scheduling process. to do so, let us first submit the maintenance orders for scheduling in the "Manage Maintenance Backlog" app. With this action we pass the maintenance orders on to the "Scheduling" phase.

I have created a maintenance planning bucket for Mechanical, Electrical, Instrumentation, and Safety work centers.

Now let us look at the backlog overview.

 

 

Once we are confident that all the required resources will be available on the required dates, we can select individual orders in the "Manage Maintenance Backlog" app and choose submit for scheduling.

Following the successful submission, the system updates the phase status.

 

Now let us view the dashboard using "Resource Scheduling for Maintenance Planners".

 

Now let us assign the person responsible for the maintenance order operations by using the card "Unassigned Work".

Now let us assign the team members to perform the job. Based on the assignment made in the "Manage Teams for Work Center" for the performing work center, the system displays the team members for each performing work center.

For Mechanical Works:

For Electrical Works:

For Instrumentation Works:

For Safety Works:

Once we assign the maintenance team members to the operations, the assignment status changes to "Assigned".

Now let us check the due maintenance order operations by priority.

Now let us add three maintenance orders to the schedule.

We can add the  due maintenance orders to the existing schedule if any, or we can create a new schedule. For Instance let us create a new schedule for the "WEEK 33".

Now the schedule status has changed to "Scoping".

Once all the work orders are assigned to the schedule "2025_CAL_MAINT_WEEK_33",  we can  use "Manage Schedule" to monitor the utilization aspects.

We can visualize the work center utilization by many attributes. For instance, let us consider processing status attribute.

Manage Schedule - List View:

Manage Schedule - Graphical View:

We have a lot many options to visualize the data.

We can change the performing work center.

 

Now let us look at the elephant in the room, i.e., "Maintenance Scheduling Board".

For Instance, let us consider the date range, work centers, and priority as per our maintenance orders.

 

and also let us select the maintenance order operations having status "DUE".

To view the work centers, we can use the option "My Work Centers".

Now let us visualize the data using the option "Orders and Resources".

we can update the constraints( Must Start Date &Time), Change Performing Work Center, Dispatch or Assign/Unassign people for the Maintenance Order Operations.

For Instance, let us update the constraint for one of the operations.

We can assign and unassign the people.

We can move the operations to next week by dragging and dropping to ensure the utilization is not more than 100%.

Now let us maintain the relationships and dispatch the operations.

We can maintain Offset/Edit Offset/Delete Offset, and create "Relationships" between operations. For Instance, let us add "2 HRs" offset to one of the operations.

We can Edit or Delete Offset or Relationship.

Once we dispatch the operations, the maintenance order phase moves to the "Execution Phase" and sub-phase moves to "Ready For Execution (Order)".

Now let us visualize the "Scheduling Overview by Asset Wise". For Instance, let us select "Belt Conveyor-01".

We can visualize an asset in its hierarchical structure. Also, we can graphically view the maintenance work planned for the asset and all its sub-assets.

 

Collaborating on a Schedule: We can share a schedule that we created or review a schedule that someone shared with us. The activity log helps us track the changes made by co-planners and reviewers of our schedule. We can also post and reply to the comments in the log.

As the maintenance orders and operations have been dispatched, let us use app. "Manage Schedule" to visualize the work center utilization and share the schedule.

First visualize the work center utilization by "Processing Status".

Now let us share with one of our peers.

 

Now, "Chandana Chelikam" reviews our schedule and provides her feedback on the schedule completeness by accessing the "Manage Schedules -For Review" app.

 

Now, let us view her feedback (activity log) and reply to her using  "Manage Schedules -For Review" app.

 

Now let us "Freeze" the schedule by choosing "Freeze Schedule" option.

Now the schedule "2025_CAL_MAINT_WEEK_33"  status becomes " FROZEN".

 

Once the schedule is "Frozen", we can no longer change the schedule. If any new operations are added and dispatched to be completed within the schedule after the schedule was frozen, then the status of those operations under "Completion In Schedule" will shown as "Dispatched In Addition".

 

Now let us track the "Execution Of a Schedule".

Once the schedule period starts, the schedule status changes to "Execution". We can start tracking schedule attainment and the completion of the order operations in our schedule. The prerequisite is that the schedule must be "Frozen" before the schedule period starts.

We can track it either using "Manage Schedule app." or "My Schedules" card in the "Resource Scheduling for Maintenance Planners app".

Once we complete the maintenance operations at shop floor, let us confirm the operations using "Perform Maintenance Jobs" app.

For Instance, let us use the option "Quick Confirm".

 

Schedule Attainment: Let us use the "Manage Schedule" app. to view the schedule attainment ratio.

Post maintenance order operations confirmations, The micro chart for the  "Attainment" shows the ratio of the work that was planned for the schedule period  and the work that was completed as planned in the schedule period.

let us visualize the operations completed in schedule between 18.08.2025 to 24.08.2025.

Mini Note: When the operations are not in the schedule at the time of the schedule freeze, and those are dispatched for and completed in the schedule period after the schedule is frozen, the status for those operations is shown as "Completed in Addition".

 

This brings me to the end of my process walk through. 😊 I hope my blog proves useful to the Maintenance Team. I look forward to seeing Maintenance Team using "Resource Scheduling"  functionality to optimize maintenance operations and enhance asset reliability.

 

--

Yours Sincerely,

Pardhasaradhi Reddy.C

entry.title: Re: Triggering Process in Shared Environments from SAP Build Apps
entry.content:
1) I need more information here: Which project does this appear? Screenshot? What are you executing at that moment? How are you displaying/seeing the message -- Alert box, developer tools, SAP Build Monitoring?

2) That's a real technical message I've never seen before.

I just wrote on LinkedIn how great the community is, and it is. But it also can be infuriating -- me and everyone here (almost) has jobs, families, hobbies -- we want to help but to make a context switch and then to understand where you are in your debugging is nearly impossible, and given that you are on your own network, perhaps controlled by your company's IT, going through how many routers and firewalls, with a SAP BTP commercial model of who knows what, using who knows what service plan, with instances and destinations set up in myriad possible ways, and with no access to see them, and with no debugging information to understand where is the problem (SAP Build Apps, SAP Build Process Automation, destination configuration, integration configuration, browser, network, Build Apps user interface) and not knowing where these messages appear (SAP Build Monitoring tab for an instance, popup in Build Apps, in Developer Tools during API call, perhaps when testing a destination in the SAP BTP cockpit) -- it's all very difficult, and we and the rest of the community are not support but people who curious and very much want to help people.

I don't mean to rant on you -- this is something I've been thinking about a long time and has been frustrating me for a long time, perhaps since 2004 and the days of SDN (at the risk of aging me) 😸

entry.title: QM- MIC - Classed Recording
entry.content:
Classed Recording is

  • Used for quantitative characteristics.
  • Instead of recording each individual measurement, record how many samples fall into defined class ranges.

Master Data Setup

Step 1: Activate Classed Recording Indicator in MIC

 

Step 2: Maintain Quantitative Data for MIC

  • Tolerance- Upper, Lower, Target
  • No of Classes with * in Class width & Class mid-point (It will Auto calculate)
 

Result Recording

In RR Screen,

  • As Maintained, No of Classes as 5. It reflected with Class Width of 4 {90-94,94-98…=5}
  • Also, an extra Class is to warn user that it's out of Specification or Tolerance.
 

After Result Recording, It show average (96.) as below

  • Avg of First Class that recorded = (90+94)/2 =92
  • Avg of Third Class that recorded = (98+102)/2 =100
  • Avg of all Class that recorded = (92+100)/2=96
 

#SAPQM

entry.title: Re: Bank Guarantee as noted item in SAP Public Cloud
entry.content:
Hello @charlene2 

The traditional Special G/L indicators for bank guarantees (E/I) are not available in S4HANA Public Cloud. Only A (customer down payment) and K (vendor down payment) are supported.

  • Simple tracking → Post a down payment (A/K) and use it as a proxy for the guarantee.
  • Full lifecycle → Use Treasury & Risk Management (FIN-TRM) with the Manage Bank Guarantees app.
  • If TRM is not in scope → Build a Custom Business Object (CBO) to capture and report guarantee details.

Bank guarantees cannot be listed as noted items in Public Cloud. Use down-payments as a proxy or TRM to represent appropriate guarantees management.

SAP Help TRM - Bank guarantee

SAP Help Bank Guarantees

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Issue with Override of Complete Delivery Flag in Sales Order Simulation API
entry.content:
Issue Summary

When using the Sales Order Simulation API (API_SALES_ORDER_SIMULATION_SRV) the parameter `CompleteDeliveryIsDefined = false` does not override the customer master setting for Complete Delivery. The system continues to enforce the Complete Delivery flag from master data, preventing partial confirmations, unlike the behavior in VA01.

Business Impact

The Commerce Cloud integration relies on the Sales Order Simulation API to provide accurate ATP results. Due to this issue, customers flagged for “Complete Delivery” in master data cannot receive partial confirmation results through API simulation, even though the payload contains  the needed ‘false’ flag. This results in inconsistent behavior between API-based processing and direct SAP GUI order creation, impacting order confirmation accuracy and eCommerce customer experience.

Question:
In VA01, when creating a Sales Order manually and removing the Complete Delivery flag, ATP check works correctly and allows partial confirmations. When Commerce Cloud sends payload to S/4 with "CompleteDeliveryIsDefined: false’ aiming to remove the complete delivery flag (like VA01), S/4 is not respecting this override and not allowing ATP to return partial confirmations.

  1. Why is this behavior different between direct GUI order creation and API-based order simulation, even when both aim to turn off the complete delivery requirement?
    2. Is there any SAP Note, configuration setting, development options, or workaround available to enable the simulation logic in S/4 to respect this flag ("CompleteDeliveryIsDefined: false’ ) and override the master data during order simulation via API?

What I know is Eclipse but it's unrelated to "Java script" (!?).

SE11 or Eclipse depends on the versions of both Eclipse ADT and the ABAP backend. In the latest versions, it will show the table as Dictionary DDL. In older versions, it will show the table via SE11 e.g. with backend ABAP 7.52 SP 4, it will show the table only via SE11, with back ABAP 7.58 it will show by default as Dictionary DDL.

Examples for the table T000:

  • Dictionary DDL:

  • SE11

For information, you may switch from Dictionary DDL to SE11 via Open With > SAP GUI (right click on the table). 

NB: you have tagged incorrectly with "SAP BTP ABAP environment" and "SAP S/4HANA Cloud ABAP Environment", in S/4HANA Cloud (i.e. Public), SAP GUI is not available. The correct tag is simply "ABAP Development" and you may add any other user tag you want.

entry.title: Re: Measures or account dimension in term of performance...
entry.content:
@Deb_D 

There is no thumb rule here but a hybrid approach is more optimized. A lot will depend on what kind of data or planning is being implemented. For a Financial Reporting /Planning, its always better to use Accounts along with measures. One thing to note is account based modelling creates more rows of data records in model. Measure based modelling creates more columns. Any keyfigure which is applicable to all rows should be pushed in measures. For e.g. Quantity/HC etc. If you need a structure in your keyfigures ( parent child ), you need to model them in accounts and Measures do not support hierarchy in itself. If you need Account Type treatment ( financial reporting case), you need to have accounts. So study all your data types that will reside in your model and then take a call where to put the metrics modelling to Accounts/Measures. In my view a hybrid approach with both seems reasonable.

Also refer to the section below for some guidance

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_ANALYTICS_CLOUD/00f68c2e08b941f081002fd3691d86a7/22af95d0151c4946b132d4e904b1e32a.html#choosing-a-model-configuration

Hope this helps !

Nikhil

entry.title: Identity Provisioning Service(IPS)-Assigning Custom Attributes to IAS Users with Transformation Expr
entry.content:
This blog explores how to assign up to 10 customAttributes values to IAS users, with the first 5 reserved for SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) Teams mapping, and how to configure this using IPS transformation expressions.

IPS Transformation Expression for Custom Attributes

To assign value to custom attributes during provisioning, IPS uses transformation expressions in the target system configuration(Identity Authentication). Here’s an example of how to assign customAttribute1:

{
    "constant": "Germany",
    "optional": true,
    "targetPath": "$['urn:sap:cloud:scim:schemas:extension:custom:2.0:User']['attributes'][0]['value']"
},
{
    "constant": "customAttribute1",
    "targetPath": "$['urn:sap:cloud:scim:schemas:extension:custom:2.0:User']['attributes'][0]['name']"
}

Explanation:

  • constant: The value to be assigned. This can be dynamic (e.g., from source attributes) or static.
  • targetPath: The JSON path in the SCIM schema where the value should be placed.
  • optional: Indicates whether the attribute is optional.

The attributes array index ([0] in this case) corresponds to the position of the custom attribute. For example:

  • attributes[0] → customAttribute1
  • attributes[1] → customAttribute2
  • ...
  • attributes[9] → customAttribute10

Assigning Value into Multiple Custom Attributes

To assign up to 10 custom attributes, repeat the transformation block with the appropriate index and attribute name. Here's a template for assigning customAttribute2:

Repeat this pattern for attributes 3 through 10.

{
    "constant": "customAttribute2",
    "optional": true,
    "targetPath": "$['urn:sap:cloud:scim:schemas:extension:custom:2.0:User']['attributes'][1]['value']"
},
{
    "constant": "customAttribute2",
    "targetPath": "$['urn:sap:cloud:scim:schemas:extension:custom:2.0:User']['attributes'][1]['name']"
}

📌SAC Teams Mapping

The first five customAttributes (customAttribute1 to customAttribute5) are typically reserved for SAC - Teams mapping. Ensure these are populated correctly to enable seamless integration with SAC.

Best Practices

  • Use meaningful names for custom attributes to maintain clarity.
  • Validate the transformation expressions in IPS before deploying.
  • Document the attribute usage to avoid conflicts across systems.
  • Test provisioning flows with sample users to ensure correct attribute mapping.

Conclusion

Using IPS transformation expressions to assign customAttributes to IAS users provides a scalable and flexible way to enrich user profiles. Whether for SAC integration or other custom use cases, this approach ensures your identity provisioning is both robust and adaptable.

entry.title: 🔗 Employee Central to Employee Central Payroll Integration Scenarios – A Technical Perspective
entry.content:
🌐️SuccessFactors EC to Employee Central Payroll Integration – Direct vs IAS-based Connectivity

👨‍💻About Me

Hare Krishna 🙏 I am an SAP BTP Cloud Architect sharing practical insights, solutions, and real-world experiences from the SAP ecosystem.

📌Introduction

When implementing Employee Central Payroll (ECP), connectivity between SuccessFactors Employee Central (EC) and Payroll plays a vital role in ensuring smooth payroll processes and seamless employee experience.

There are two main scenarios for this connectivity:

  1. ⚡Direct Connectivity – EC communicates with ECP without Identity Authentication Service (IAS).

  2. 🔒IAS-enabled Connectivity – EC communicates with ECP via SAP Cloud Identity Services - Identity Authentication (IAS).

Both approaches are valid, and depending on customer security policies, infrastructure readiness, and implementation strategy, one or the other may be chosen.

🎯Key Functionalities Enabled Through EC ↔ ECP Connectivity

Once the integration between SuccessFactors EC and ECP is established, organizations can leverage the following key functionalities:

  • 🧾 Direct Payslip Access from EC – Employees can view their pay statements directly in the EC Payroll Information tab.

  • 🔄Real-time Data Access – Payroll data and reports from ECP are available in EC.

  • ⚡Support Package Level Visibility – Administrators can check the ECP Support Package (SP) level from the EC interface.

  • 🆙Request ECP Support Package Upgrades – Through EC Upgrade Center, admins can request support package updates for ECP.

  • 🔐Seamless Authentication and SSO – Depending on the architecture, employees enjoy single sign-on across EC and ECP.

🏗️ Architecture Scenarios

1️⃣Direct Connectivity (EC → ECP)

In this approach, the connection is established directly between EC and ECP without an additional identity layer.

   🌐 SuccessFactors EC
          │
          ▼
   🖥️ Employee Central Payroll (ECP)

✔️Highlights

  • Simpler connectivity model.

  • No additional identity provider configuration.

  • Suitable for rapid implementations.

⚠️Considerations

  • Authentication handled directly at ECP level.

  • Less flexible for future cloud identity expansions.

2️⃣Connectivity with IAS (EC → IAS → ECP)

In this approach, SAP IAS acts as the identity layer, managing authentication and providing enhanced security.

   🌐 SuccessFactors EC
          │
          ▼
   🔑 SAP Identity Authentication Service (IAS)
          │
          ▼
   🖥️ Employee Central Payroll (ECP)

✔️Highlights

  • Centralized identity management.

  • Better alignment with SAP’s long-term cloud security strategy.

  • Easier integration with other SAP SaaS products.

⚠️Considerations

  • Requires additional configuration of IAS tenants.

  • Slightly more complex to implement initially.

⚙️Automation via Upgrade Center

SAP has simplified IAS setup for ECP through Upgrade Center automation in SuccessFactors:

  • Navigate to Admin Center → Upgrade Center.

  • Select Employee Central Payroll IAS Integration.

  • Choose “Learn More & Upgrade Now” to automate IAS enablement.

💡This eliminates multiple manual steps and ensures standardization across environments.

📊Comparison of Connectivity Approaches

🏷️ Criteria                                    ⚡ Direct Connectivity (EC → ECP)                                🔒 IAS-based Connectivity (EC → IAS → ECP)
Architecture Simplicity✅Simple, fewer components involved⚠️Slightly complex due to IAS layer
AuthenticationHandled directly by ECPCentralized in IAS (cloud standard)
Implementation SpeedFaster setup, minimal stepsRequires IAS tenant setup & configuration
Security & ComplianceBasic securityEnhanced security with SSO & centralized identity
Future-readinessLimited flexibility for integration with other cloud products🌍Recommended by SAP for long-term roadmap
Upgrade PathManual checks & upgradesSupported with Upgrade Center automation
Best Use CaseRapid go-live, smaller landscapesEnterprises with strong security requirements & multi-cloud strategy

🖼️ Key Implementation Screenshot

Figure : SuccessFactors Provisioning – SAML ACS URL Configuration
Below is an example screenshot from SuccessFactors Provisioning where we configure the Assertion Consumer Service (ACS) URL.

  • This ACS URL can either point to IAS (Identity Authentication Service) or directly to ECP (Employee Central Payroll), depending on the chosen architecture.

  • This configuration plays a crucial role in how authentication and single sign-on (SSO) are managed between EC and ECP.

Post updating the URL here, You can download the metadata from here and update it in IAS or ECP system as per the approach you follow. Follow the Step by Step documentation with screenshots from SAP for performing the scenarios. (Check Reference column at the end of the blog for links to SAP documentation).

👥User Provisioning & Authorization in ECP

For EC ↔ ECP integration to work (Direct or IAS-based), users must exist and have correct roles in ECP.

🔑Key Requirements

  • User Existence: Each employee must have a user master (SU01) in ECP.

  • Consistent IDs: EC, ECP, and IAS (if used) must share the same identifier (e.g., User ID).

  • Authorizations: Roles and objects required include:

    • Payroll Control Center (PCC) roles such as Process Manager / Process Modeler.

    • Authorization objects like P_PYT_CFG for payroll configuration.

    • Employee / Manager roles for payslip access.

    • Admin roles for payroll system configuration and SP upgrades.

📋Summary Table

Area Required Access
Employee Payslip AccessPayroll report / HR employee role
PCC FunctionsPCC roles (Process Manager, Modeler, etc.)
System ConfigurationAdmin roles for payroll setup & upgrades

👉Note: Authentication only confirms identity. Correct authorization is what finally enables payslip view and payroll activities in ECP.

✨Key Takeaways

  • Both Direct Connectivity and IAS-based Connectivity are supported.

  • Organizations with simpler landscapes or faster timelines may prefer Direct Connectivity.

  • Organizations with long-term cloud roadmaps and enhanced security needs should choose IAS-based Connectivity.

  • Upgrade Center automation makes IAS setup easier, reducing manual administrative work.

❓FAQs

Q1: Do I always need IAS for EC ↔ ECP integration?
➡️No. Direct connectivity is still supported, but IAS is recommended for cloud security and future readiness.

Q2: What’s the main difference in authentication between the two models?
➡️In direct connectivity, authentication is managed at ECP. In IAS model, authentication is centralized in IAS.

Q3: Can I request ECP Support Package (SP) upgrades via EC?
➡️Yes. Once connectivity is established, EC provides visibility into ECP SP levels and you can raise upgrade requests.

Q4: Is the IAS setup manual or automated?
➡️Initially, it was manual. Now, Upgrade Center automation simplifies the setup process significantly.

📚References

  • SAP Note 2253359 – Employee Central Payroll: Access to Payroll application (payslip)

  • SAP Help Documentation – SAP Cloud Identity Services – Identity Authentication for Employee Central Payroll Configuration Steps

  • SAP Help Documentation – Automation of SAP Cloud Identity Services (IAS) using Upgrade Center

entry.title: Re: OpenText xECM connect with S/4Hana Public Cloud
entry.content:
Hello @VenkyJ 

Thank you for the follow-up.

 Yes, there are two workable patterns, both Public Cloud–friendly:

1) Standard OpenText integration (xECM/Archive Center packages)
This setup is configuration-based, requiring no custom coding in S/4HANA. SAP Cloud Integration manages the hand-off, while OpenText maps the business metadata such as object type (e.g., SupplierInvoice or PurchaseOrder), object key/UUID, company code, fiscal year, document date, vendor/customer, document type, file name, and MIME type. Attachments are stored in OpenText and linked to the corresponding S/4HANA business object.

2) Custom, API-based
Use S/4HANA Public Cloud OData APIs to access the business object, initiate the send, and then invoke OpenText REST APIs from SAP Cloud Integration (CPI). The file is sent as a multipart, with metadata in JSON format, for instance

{

  "businessObject": "SupplierInvoice",

  "objectUUID": "…",

  "companyCode": "1010",

  "fiscalYear": "2025",

  "documentNumber": "5100…",

  "vendor": "1000123",

  "postingDate": "2025-08-15",

  "documentType": "KR",

  "fileName": "SI_5100….pdf",

  "mimeType": "application/pdf",

  "sourceSystem": "S4HC-GB"

}

You can also return the OpenText document ID/URL to S/4 as an attachment link for round-trips.

Invoice PDFs and delivery notes from S/4HANA Public Cloud to OpenText, using event-based triggers such as SupplierInvoice.Created via SAP Event Mesh → CPI → OpenText, including full metadata mapping and link-back.

 

What’s new in OpenText Core Content Management

 

Let me know if you need further support

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: How can I change growing to scroll in a Fiori element...
entry.content:
To get this you need to tell framework how many records you are going to send first see below code:

      DATA(lv_offset) = io_request->get_paging( )->get_offset( ).
      DATA(lv_page_size) = io_request->get_paging( )->get_page_size( ).
      DATA(lv_max_rows) = COND #( WHEN lv_page_size = if_rap_query_paging=>page_size_unlimited THEN 0
                                  ELSE lv_page_size ).
      "check count
      SELECT COUNT( * )
      FROM vbkpf AS vbkpf
      WHERE vbkpf~bukrs IN @RA_bukrs
      AND vbkpf~ausbk IN @RA_bukrs
      AND vbkpf~belnr IN @RA_belnr
      AND vbkpf~gjahr IN @RA_gjahr
      AND vbkpf~budat IN @RA_budat
      AND vbkpf~bldat IN @RA_bldat
      AND vbkpf~blart IN @RA_blart
      AND vbkpf~bktxt IN @RA_bktxt
      AND vbkpf~xblnr IN @RA_xblnr
      AND vbkpf~usnam IN @RA_usnam
      AND vbkpf~bstat EQ 'V'
      AND vbkpf~xwffr IN @RA_xwffr
      AND vbkpf~xfrge IN @RA_xfrge
      AND vbkpf~xprfg IN @RA_xprfg
      AND ( vbkpf~awtyp IN (@awtyp_bkpf, @awtyp_space) OR
            vbkpf~awtyp IS NULL ) INTO @DATA(lv_lines).

SELECT  vbkpf~usnam, vbkpf~belnr, vbkpf~gjahr, vbkpf~bukrs, vbkpf~ausbk, vbkpf~blart, vbkpf~budat, vbkpf~waers, vbkpf~xblnr,
                  vbkpf~bktxt, vbkpf~xwffr, vbkpf~xprfg, vbkpf~xfrge
           FROM vbkpf AS vbkpf
           WHERE vbkpf~bukrs IN @RA_bukrs
           AND vbkpf~ausbk IN @RA_bukrs
           AND vbkpf~belnr IN @RA_belnr
           AND vbkpf~gjahr IN @RA_gjahr
           AND vbkpf~budat IN @RA_budat
           AND vbkpf~bldat IN @RA_bldat
           AND vbkpf~blart IN @RA_blart
           AND vbkpf~bktxt IN @RA_bktxt
           AND vbkpf~xblnr IN @RA_xblnr
           AND vbkpf~usnam IN @RA_usnam
*           AND vbkpf~waers IN @RA_waers
           AND vbkpf~bstat EQ 'V'
           AND vbkpf~xwffr IN @RA_xwffr
           AND vbkpf~xfrge IN @RA_xfrge
           AND vbkpf~xprfg IN @RA_xprfg
           AND ( vbkpf~awtyp IN (@awtyp_bkpf, @awtyp_space) OR
                 vbkpf~awtyp IS NULL )
           ORDER BY belnr, gjahr, vbkpf~bukrs
           INTO CORRESPONDING FIELDS OF TABLE  @INT_output
           OFFSET @LV_offset UP TO @LV_max_rows ROWS.

      TRY.
          IF io_request->is_total_numb_of_rec_requested( ).
            io_response->set_total_number_of_records( lv_lines ).
            io_response->set_data( int_output ).
          ELSE.
            io_response->set_total_number_of_records( lv_lines ).
            io_response->set_data( int_output ).
          ENDIF.
        CATCH cx_rap_query_response_set_twic.
      ENDTRY.

entry.title: Re: Additional Charges in Sales Invoice
entry.content:
Hello @Dinesh_158 

The goal is to show a delivery charge on the SD invoice, collect it from the customer, but keep it out of the Revenue post to a separate G/L.

Here's a simple guide on setting up S/4HANA Public Cloud.

1.Pricing

  • Create a surcharge condition (e.g., ZFRT) and add it to your sales pricing procedure so it increases the invoice total.
  • Assign an account key (copy FRE or create ZFR) to the condition in the pricing procedure. Scribe SAP Community

2. Account determination (Sales)

  • In CBC → Sales → Account Determination, map the account key (e.g., ZFR) to a non-revenue G/L such as Freight recovery/clearing or Other operating income G/L. This ensures that the billing document posts a separate FI line that is not ERL revenue.  fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com

3. Tax

  • Set tax behaviour based on the condition, so it complies with your jurisdictional rule often, and delivery charges follow the main item's VAT rate. Validate in your tax procedure/config. SAP Learning

Operational options -You can choose one

  • True pass-through or clearing requires posting after ZFRT to a balance sheet clearing G/L. Record your actual delivery cost FI document against the same G/L to ensure it balances to zero.
  • Non-revenue income: Post ZFRT to Other Operating Income (separate P&L G/L), leaving product revenue unaffected.

Here's why this approach is effective!

The surcharge forms part of the invoice total, so you receive cash, but the account determination directs it away from revenue to the G/L you select. No custom code is required, only pricing and account determination that are supported in Public Cloud. fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com

Let me know if you need further support

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Issue with Override of Complete Delivery Flag in Sale...
entry.content:
The discrepancy arises because VA01 operates with full transactional context, allowing dynamic overrides of master data settings like the Complete Delivery flag. In contrast, the Sales Order Simulation API is designed for read-only ATP simulation, and it does not fully replicate the override logic of VA01.

Even though you're passing CompleteDeliveryIsDefined = false, the API simulation logic still prioritizes the customer master data setting, treating it as authoritative. This is a known limitation in how simulation APIs interpret delivery rules.

Below are some workarounds

Use VA01 or BAPI instead of simulation of API. If partial confirmation is critical, consider using BAPI_SALESORDER_CREATEFROMDAT2 for actual order creation with override logic. Or simulate using BAPI-based logic that respects dynamic flags more closely than the simulation API.

Preprocess Customer Master Data as a temporary workaround by unsetting the Complete Delivery flag in the customer master data before simulation. Reapply it afterward if needed. This is not ideal but ensures simulation reflects partial delivery logic.

Keep an eye on SAP Notes related to API_SALES_ORDER_SIMULATION_SRV. You can track updates via SAP’s Help Portal or SAP Notes Search.

entry.title: Re: Extract taxe codes with NVV operation
entry.content:
In SAP, the NVV account key you see in FTXP isn’t directly stored in the tax code itself. Instead, it’s part of the tax procedure assigned to that tax code. Within the procedure, specific condition types (like MWST or NAV) are configured to use account keys such as NVV or VST. So when you select a tax code in FTXP, SAP displays the account key based on the condition type logic — not because the tax code is inherently linked to NVV. That’s why you might see VST in T030K even though NVV appears in FTXP — they’re tied to different condition types within the same procedure.”

Here’s how the components interact:

So, when you see NVV in FTXP, it’s because the condition type used in the tax procedure for that tax code is configured to post using NVV. The tax code itself doesn’t store NVV — it inherits it through this configuration chain.

This distinction is important when analyzing tax postings or troubleshooting inconsistencies:

  • FTXP shows NVV → because of the condition type logic in the tax procedure.
  • T030K shows VST → because another condition type in the same procedure may be using VST for deductible VAT.

entry.title: Re: Additional Charges in Sales Invoice
entry.content:
For this Business requirement, instead of Account Key, I recommend going with an Accrual Key.  Try with the below approach

Use SAP Central Business Configuration (CBC) or SSCUI #101120 to define a new condition type (e.g., ZDEL). Set Condition Class = ‘A’, Condition Category = ‘F’, Calculation Type = ‘B’ and Plus/Minus Indicator = Positive.

In the pricing procedure, assign an accrual key (e.g., ZDEL) to this condition type. This key should be mapped in T030K to a delivery expense G/L account, not a revenue account.

Insert the new condition type into your pricing procedure after the net price but before taxes. Ensure it’s marked as statistical if you don’t want it to affect net revenue calculations.

Use the “Set Material Prices – Sales” Fiori app to maintain condition records for the new delivery charge.

With this setup:

  • The delivery charge appears on the sales invoice.
  • It posts to a delivery expense account via the accrual key.
  • It does not hit the revenue G/L, preserving accurate revenue reporting.

entry.title: Re: Project Systems error on 'Aggregation Levels invalid'
entry.content:
For the error “Resource not found for the segment 'PlanData'”, this typically means the OData service is either:

  • not properly activated in the backend system
  • Misreferenced in the URL (case sensitivity matters!)
  • Missing required metadata or entity definitions

SAP Note 1797736 refers to general OData errors and may not directly resolve this unless the service is incorrectly configured. Make sure the service /sap/opu/odata/sap/API_FINPLANNINGDATA_SRV is active in /IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE. You’re using the correct entity set name: FinancialPlanData is the valid one for writing data, not PlanData (which may not exist as a segment)

For the other error “Aggregation levels invalid”, this is a semantic validation error. It means the combination of fields you're posting doesn’t match any valid Aggregation Level defined in your system. In SAP S/4HANA Financial Planning, Aggregation Levels are defined in the backend and determine which dimensions (e.g., Company Code, Cost Center, GL Account) are required for planning data. To resolve this use the Read API (API_FINPLANNINGENTRYITEM_SRV) to fetch valid combinations of aggregation levels. Check the Planning Model and Planning Category in your payload—these must match what's configured in your system. Ensure all mandatory dimensions for the aggregation level are filled with valid values

Yes, you can use partial payloads, but only if the omitted fields are not mandatory for the aggregation level. You’re not sending empty strings ("") for fields that expect structured values. If you leave fields as "string" or empty, SAP may still try to validate them, leading to errors. Instead omit optional fields entirely from the payload. Use proper null handling or default values if required

Finally, use API Hub examples provided in this SAP's API Hub reference
